This is a fine musical with a timeless score by one of my favorite composers (Gershwin) and a nice 'Parisien' atmosphere which gives the Boston Covenant Players an excuse to move out of their normal New England-English setting, which they regularly excelled at in Downton Abbey. 'An American Rom-Rom' needs a little more spunk or it misses the mark.

Well,I am a dancer so automatically I liked this film. The only thing I didn't like was they didn't have much dancing as I thought there would be, replacing more dialogue. There were some things that threw me off that made me wonder if other fans would agree with me during certain parts too. However, Christine still is very powerful in this and her emotion definitely makes up for the shortfalls.

I had mixed feelings for "Les Valseuses" (1974) written and directed by Bertrand Blier when I started watching it but I ended up loving it. "Les Valseuses" was remade as the 1978 American classic "Midnight Cowboy" and strangely enough a pretty decent version of that film is currently in the works titled "Midnites Children". Both the original French film found on MGM and Criterion's Criterion Blu-ray of Midnight Cowboy

If you are a fan of Zorro, Indiana Jones, or action in general this is a must-see. Directed by Republic's ace team of William Witney and John English and starring John Carroll as the title character. Some minor plot differences that make this agreeable. Recommended.
